Comprehensive Program Overview for Trainers
This document provides trainers with a complete overview of the 6-day intensive solar training program designed for implementation in Mosul, Iraq. It captures the evolution of our training design through collaborative refinement.

Program Context & Need
Mosul faces significant energy challenges that create both problems and opportunities:

Power outages: Typical homes experience 16+ hours of outages weekly
High energy costs: Diesel generators cost families approximately 250 IQD/kWh
Job potential: The solar industry can create thousands of local jobs
Climate advantage: Mosul's high solar irradiance (5+ peak sun hours daily) makes solar systems highly effective
Target Audience
This program is designed for:

Electrical/mechanical engineers transitioning to renewable energy
Technicians with basic electrical knowledge
Construction professionals interested in solar installation
Entrepreneurs looking to enter the growing solar market
Participants should have basic technical knowledge but do not need prior solar experience.

Core Learning Objectives
By the end of this program, participants will be able to:

Technical Competencies:
Conduct thorough site assessments and load calculations
Size and design complete solar PV systems
Select appropriate components based on technical specifications
Install solar systems safely following industry standards
Commission and troubleshoot installations professionally
Document system details using industry-standard forms
Business Competencies:
Calculate system costs and prepare professional quotations
Demonstrate financial benefits to potential customers
Develop service offerings for recurring revenue
Manage project cash flow effectively
Market solar services effectively in the local context
Pedagogical Approach & Principles
Our training methodology is built on these foundational principles:

Practical Before Theoretical: 70% hands-on activities, 30% classroom instruction
Local Relevance: All examples, costs, and scenarios specific to Mosul context
Progressive Complexity: Skills build systematically day by day
Authentic Materials: Using real equipment, documentation, and industry forms
Business Integration: Technical and business skills taught together
Safety Culture: Safety protocols embedded throughout all activities
Simple Language: Clear explanations that avoid unnecessary jargon

Day 1: Context, Site Auditing & Load Analysis
Learning Objectives:

Explain Iraq's energy gap and solar opportunity
Differentiate between PV system architectures (off-grid, on-grid, hybrid)
Conduct comprehensive site surveys using proper tools
Calculate accurate load profiles for residential applications
Create horizon sketches and interpret sun-path diagrams
Key Activities:

Interactive lecture on solar fundamentals
Field walk audit and site survey practice
Load calculation workshop with realistic appliances
Sun-path analysis and horizon sketching
Daily reflection and WhatsApp voice summary

Explain advanced panel technologies and their benefits

Digital tools introduction (PVWatts, Viktor)
Component technology comparisons

* **Day 3** – *Safety*: especially DC vs AC wiring, correct DC cables, breakers, fuses—people ignore this in Iraq.  
* **Days 4-5** – *Design & installation*: shading analysis, array layout, mounting angles, using the “Solar Pathfinder” to see shadow lengths in winter vs summer; then hands-on assembly.

**BILAL:**

Exactly—on Day 5 give them a load profile and tell them: “Design the system, price it, choose components, justify it.” Then on Day 6 they present.

**BILAL:**
